text: English writing skills punctuation marks
lesson six in this lesson we'll practice
writing titles and names titles of
artistic works names of artists and more
and I'll explain when we need commas
with adjective clauses finally we'll
take a look at the use of quotation
marks to set up words with a special
meaning
hello everyone let's talk about movies
specifically movies about magical powers
and special abilities do you know the
movie phenomenon from the 1990s John
Travolta plays a simple man who receives
a gift
let's punctuate these two sentences the
first is a question we have a capital
letter to start our sentence and we have
a question mark as our final sentence
punctuation that's good but there is a
mistake do you see it
first of all I hope you know that it's
not here that is correct
remember from our previous lesson that
we do not need an apostrophe to refer to
the decade 1990s the mistake is here we
have a title of a movie but how do we
show that it's the title of a movie
first we'll capitalize the P we have one
word as the title we're going to
capitalize that word if we had a larger
title a longer title we would capitalize
the first letter of all main words
principal words content words important
words whatever you want to call them
okay but we need to do something more
because I'm writing by hand I'm going to
underline the title of this movie this
title of an artistic work usually when
you write these days you're on a
computer though on a computer you would
place this title in italics those
slanted letters so to show a title of a
large artistic work such as a movie a
book a play a musical a TV show you
capitalize the first letter of the first
word and then all principle words and
you place that title
in italics if you happen to be writing
by hand you can underline the title okay
moving on
John Travolta is a name of a person this
is a proper noun let's be sure to
capitalize the J and the T first name
and last name he plays a simple man who
receives a gift here we have an
adjective clause we have this
information and it's describing the noun
man the question is do we need a comma
right here to answer that question you
have to understand is this information
necessary for additional is it extra and
could we leave it out know this
information in the adjective clause is
necessary it identifies man because it's
identifying the noun we do not need a
comma commas are used to set off
adjective clauses that give extra
information that could be left out
that's not the case here so no comma
finally I'm going to use double
quotation marks a round gift making sure
my period falls inside the double
quotation marks but why this isn't
direct speech listen to my voice for a
clue John Travolta plays a simple man
who receives a gift I'm setting this
word off because I'm using a special
meaning not the usual one I don't mean a
box that's nicely gift-wrapped I'm
talking about something different
something special a gift
let's continue talking about the movie
phenomenon we've already talked about
John Travolta's character George now let
me tell you about George's love interest
lace lace who is played by Kyra Sedgwick
learns to accept George's special powers
first let's talk about the adjective
clause do you see it who is played by
Kyra Sedgwick does this adjective clause
give necessary information or extra
information could we take the clause out
and would the statement make sense yes I
could say lace learns to accept George's
special powers makes perfect sense
because this gives extra information
it's additional I'm going to set off the
adjective clause with commas if I were
to read this aloud my voice would
recognize those commas with a slight
pause and slightly lower intonation
listen lace who is played by Kyra
Sedgwick learns to accept George's
special powers do you hear the drop and
then I go up again alright now let's
talk about names capitalized good Kyra
Sedgwick first name last name needs to
be capitalized
George whose power George's power or
powers okay
capitalizing Oliver names are proper
names let me share some other names from
the cast and crew of phenomenon here's
one Sean O'Brien this actor has an Irish
name look how his last name is written
this format is seen in many other Irish
last names O'Hara
O'Malley O'Rourke they all have an O '
and then another capital letter you'll
see a similar pattern in many Italian
last names
Halle d'amour a Justin to pick oh my
pronunciation may be off but the format
is correct
here's one Donnie Macmillan Donnie has a
Scottish last name
whether it's Mick or Mac you'll also see
two capital letters within the last name
Macmillan mix teen McDonald McCallister
Bruce ayoung is another actor in the
film
Bruce has a middle name but we don't
know it because he only gives his middle
initial a the first letter whether it's
an initial for a middle name or first
name initials must be written with
uppercase letters they're followed by
periods and we separate them with a
space now look at three more names Craig
B Eyre senior Alejandro Diaz junior
senior junior refer to father and son so
Craig has a son with the same name
Alejandro has a father with the same
name George a castle the third well his
name is pretty common in his family
there are three men with the same name
and he's the third
do you know the soundtrack is a
soundtrack is all the music from a film
a lot of the music that I listened to
comes from my favorite movies as for
phenomenon the film has a good
soundtrack with songs like have a little
faith in me look at this sentence
capital letter period looks pretty good
but here we have a title a title of what
a song first let's capitalize the words
that need to be capitalized the first
letter of the first word and all
important words so not an article but an
adjective and now and this pronoun this
is a preposition a short one we don't
need to capitalize it this is a song
compared to a book a movie a much larger
artistic work songs are relatively small
artistic works we don't use italics we
use quotation marks this is the end of
my statement so my period falls inside
the double quotation marks have a little
faith in me
is the name of the song the title other
examples of smaller artistic works let
me thank our songs poems short stories
those are some common examples
so again larger artistic works are
placed in italics or you can underline
if you're writing by hand but regardless
of whether you're writing by hand or
typing on a computer use quotation marks
around smaller artistic works this is
the end of part 1 please go on to the
